item.title: U.S. Supply Of Yellow Fever Vaccine Will Run Out By Midsummer
item.description: April 28, 2017 - Officials are working on an emergency import deal for another vaccine that is not licensed in the U.S. Even then, a limited number of doses will be available at only a small number of clinics.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 28, 2017 - Officials are working on an emergency import deal for another vaccine that is not licensed in the U.S. Even then, a limited number of doses will be available at only a small number of clinics. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/28/526067401/u-s-supply-of-yellow-fever-vaccine-will-run-out-by-midsummer

item.title: His Parents' Death Gave Him A Mission: Stop The Medical Brain Drain
item.description: April 28, 2017 - Chris Ategeka left his native Uganda and earned an engineering degree in the U.S. He could have gone to Silicon Valley — but his personal history set him on a different path.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 28, 2017 - Chris Ategeka left his native Uganda and earned an engineering degree in the U.S. He could have gone to Silicon Valley — but his personal history set him on a different path. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/28/525756657/his-parents-death-gave-him-a-mission-stop-the-medical-brain-drain

item.title: For Some, Pre-Hospice Care Can Be A Good Alternative To Hospitals
item.description: April 28, 2017 - Through home visits, very ill people get help with pain, stress and symptoms. Medical centers, initially skeptical, now embrace the program because it helps patients and makes financial sense.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 28, 2017 - Through home visits, very ill people get help with pain, stress and symptoms. Medical centers, initially skeptical, now embrace the program because it helps patients and makes financial sense. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/28/524512767/for-some-pre-hospice-care-can-be-a-good-alternative-to-hospitals

item.title: New Health Care Bill Needs Moderate Republicans' Support — What Do They Want?
item.description: April 27, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish talks with moderate Republican Congressman Leonard Lance of New Jersey about what he's looking for in the new health care bill.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 27, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish talks with moderate Republican Congressman Leonard Lance of New Jersey about what he's looking for in the new health care bill. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/27/525918227/new-health-care-bill-needs-moderate-republicans-support-what-do-they-want

item.title: Because I Was Harmed
item.description:
April 27, 2017 - An advocate against female genital mutilation/cutting explains: "I wanted to break the sense of powerlessness that persists generation after generation."
- http://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2017/04/27/483713242/because-i-was-harmed
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: As Trump And Congress Flip-Flop On Health Care, Insurers Try To Plan Ahead
item.description: April 27, 2017 - Insurance companies face deadlines to offer Affordable Care Act plans for next year, but lawmakers and the White House have left key decisions up in the air.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 27, 2017 - Insurance companies face deadlines to offer Affordable Care Act plans for next year, but lawmakers and the White House have left key decisions up in the air. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/27/525754974/as-trump-and-congress-flip-flop-on-health-care-insurers-try-to-plan-ahead

item.title: Scientists Hunt Hard Evidence On How Cop Cameras Affect Behavior
item.description: April 27, 2017 - Police departments in about 95 percent of cities nationally have put wearable cameras on officers, or soon plan to. But do these body cameras make neighborhoods safer? Scientists want to find out.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 27, 2017 - Police departments in about 95 percent of cities nationally have put wearable cameras on officers, or soon plan to. But do these body cameras make neighborhoods safer? Scientists want to find out. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/04/27/525081998/scientists-hunt-hard-evidence-on-how-cop-cameras-affect-behavior

item.title: ProPublica Investigation Finds Nursing Homes Waste Tons Of Prescription Drugs
item.description: April 27, 2017 - A ProPublica investigation reveals nursing homes waste millions of dollars in prescription drugs every year. NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with ProPublica's Marshall Allen about his reporting.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 27, 2017 - A ProPublica investigation reveals nursing homes waste millions of dollars in prescription drugs every year. NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with ProPublica's Marshall Allen about his reporting. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/27/525833212/propublica-investigation-finds-nursing-homes-waste-tons-of-prescription-drugs

item.title: Welcome To The Poison Garden: Medicine's Medieval Roots
item.description: April 27, 2017 - One corner of the garden of Alnwick Castle in northern England grows a hundred plants behind lock and key. Many of the toxic species there were used by medieval doctors — nasty plants adapted to heal.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 27, 2017 - One corner of the garden of Alnwick Castle in northern England grows a hundred plants behind lock and key. Many of the toxic species there were used by medieval doctors — nasty plants adapted to heal. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/27/525143152/welcome-to-the-poison-garden-medicines-medieval-roots

item.title: Overlooked Drug Could Save Thousands Of Moms After Childbirth
item.description: April 26, 2017 - An inexpensive drug could dramatically reduce the number of deaths of mothers from bleeding after childbirth in low- and middle-income countries around the world.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - An inexpensive drug could dramatically reduce the number of deaths of mothers from bleeding after childbirth in low- and middle-income countries around the world. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/26/525639110/overlooked-drug-could-save-thousands-of-moms-after-childbirth

item.title: Shutdown Averted: White House Backs Down On Health Care Demands
item.description: April 26, 2017 - The White House appears to be backing down on multiple demands that were threatening a partial government shutdown, including withholding subsidies to help low-income people under Obamacare.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - The White House appears to be backing down on multiple demands that were threatening a partial government shutdown, including withholding subsidies to help low-income people under Obamacare. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/26/525764683/shutdown-averted-white-house-backs-down-on-health-care-demands

item.title: Tyson Foods Promises Better Conditions And Safety For Meat Workers
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Meat-processing employs more than a half-million people. An investigation found they've got some of the most dangerous factory jobs in America and suffer from injury, low pay and lack of work breaks.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Meat-processing employs more than a half-million people. An investigation found they've got some of the most dangerous factory jobs in America and suffer from injury, low pay and lack of work breaks. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/26/525736888/tyson-foods-promises-better-conditions-and-safety-for-meat-workers

item.title: 'Minibrains' In A Dish Shed A Little Light On Autism And Epilepsy
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Experiments with small clusters of networked brain cells are helping scientists see how real brains develop normally, and what goes awry when cells have trouble making connections.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Experiments with small clusters of networked brain cells are helping scientists see how real brains develop normally, and what goes awry when cells have trouble making connections. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/26/525705550/minibrains-in-a-dish-shed-a-little-light-on-autism-and-epilepsy

item.title: How A Wild Berry Is Helping To Protect China's Giant Pandas And Its Countryside
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Long before it became a "superfood" in the U.S., schisandra was made into soups and jams and prized as a medicinal plant. Now the berry is at the center of a dramatic new approach to conservation.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Long before it became a "superfood" in the U.S., schisandra was made into soups and jams and prized as a medicinal plant. Now the berry is at the center of a dramatic new approach to conservation. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/26/525552957/how-a-wild-berry-helped-save-china-s-giant-pandas-and-its-countryside

item.title: Binge Drinkers Beware: Study Finds Link Between Alcohol And Heart Arrhythmias
item.description: April 26, 2017 - Researchers tested more than 3,000 people at Munich's Oktoberfest beer festival. They found getting drunk was associated with abnormal heart rhythms.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 26, 2017 - Researchers tested more than 3,000 people at Munich's Oktoberfest beer festival. They found getting drunk was associated with abnormal heart rhythms. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/26/525579920/binge-drinkers-beware-study-finds-link-between-alcohol-and-heart-arrhythmias
